title: How to Win at Words with Friends

steps.headline: Memorize the words that pros play almost every game.
Practice playing two letter words over and over, to allow you to get higher points.
steps.description: Pretty soon you'll have the hang of using common words like AT or BE strung along next to WWF favorites like RE and AB.

steps.headline: Whenever you can, play the letters "u" "c" and "v." Having them in your hand hurts you because they have almost no two letter combos, are hard to play, and just sit in your hand slowing you down.
Don't be afraid to play that Q or Z even if the result doesn't earn a ton of points.
steps.description: This is especially helpful if it's slowing you down or causing you to not do well; sometimes you just need to get rid of obscure letters.

steps.headline: Try to get letters that combine into big words easily.
steps.description: Example, get an i, n, g at the same time. Or e, d.  Or, r, e.

steps.headline: Play on "defense".
steps.description: Make sure you don't open the door for your opponent to earn big points. Avoid situations where you open up the triple word score for the opponent.

steps.headline: Look for big combinations of bonus points.
steps.description: There are a few places on the board that allow you to score double word score, twice in the same word. They give you even more points that the shiny triple word scores, so try to use them!

steps.headline: Thwart your opponent where you can.
steps.description: Some experts try very hard to close off every possible move for the opponent. It works for some. Try it if you haven't done so; it may work for you.

steps.headline: Try saving your moves for when your friend is at work or busy.
steps.description: That way s/he will be tempted to make a quick move that is low points.

text: Finding the Right Word Memorize the words that pros play almost every game. They are "Qi," "Za," "Xu" and "Ex." Practice playing two letter words over and over, to allow you to get higher points. Pretty soon you'll have the hang of using common words like AT or BE strung along next to WWF favorites like RE and AB. Managing your Letters Whenever you can, play the letters "u" "c" and "v." Having them in your hand hurts you because they have almost no two letter combos, are hard to play, and just sit in your hand slowing you down.  Don't be afraid to play that Q or Z even if the result doesn't earn a ton of points. This is especially helpful if it's slowing you down or causing you to not do well; sometimes you just need to get rid of obscure letters. Try to get letters that combine into big words easily. Example, get an i, n, g at the same time. Or e, d.  Or, r, e. Play on "defense". Make sure you don't open the door for your opponent to earn big points. Avoid situations where you open up the triple word score for the opponent. Expert Strategies Look for big combinations of bonus points. There are a few places on the board that allow you to score double word score, twice in the same word. They give you even more points that the shiny triple word scores, so try to use them! Thwart your opponent where you can. Some experts try very hard to close off every possible move for the opponent. It works for some. Try it if you haven't done so; it may work for you. Try saving your moves for when your friend is at work or busy. That way s/he will be tempted to make a quick move that is low points.
